<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 326, 294]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 299, 153, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 278, 905, 335]]<|/det|>
0606/11 October/November 2017 2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 437, 375]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper. Additional Materials: Electronic calculator  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 719, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 282, 515]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 515, 828, 560]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question. The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 559, 604, 574]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 584, 760, 629]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. The total number of marks for this paper is 80.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 73, 599, 91]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 164, 561, 182]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 195, 240, 213]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 225, 383, 244]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\),  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 243, 591, 280]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}.\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 301, 228, 319]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[243, 322, 754, 363]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n},\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 370, 500, 406]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 470, 594, 489]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 502, 156, 520]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[416, 530, 584, 602]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 629, 242, 647]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 653, 588, 686]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 705, 593, 725]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[438, 732, 558, 761]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 895, 109]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is \(ax^{3} + bx^{2} - 13x + 4\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers. Given that \(2x - 1\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) and also a factor of \(\mathrm{p}'(x)\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 121, 143, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 121, 374, 139]]<|/det|>
find the value of \(a\) and of \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 494, 348, 512]]<|/det|>
Using your values of \(a\) and \(b\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 524, 141, 543]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 523, 546, 543]]<|/det|>
find the remainder when \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divided by \(x + 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 523, 920, 542]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 146, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 598, 98]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 97]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 450, 146, 469]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 445, 712, 470]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 450, 920, 469]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 111]]<|/det|>
When \(\mathrm{lg}y\) is plotted against \(x^{2}\) a straight line is obtained which passes through the points (4, 3) and (12, 7).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 246, 920, 265]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 540, 141, 559]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 540, 920, 574]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 466, 920, 485]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 71, 868, 91]]<|/det|>
10 people are to be chosen, to receive concert tickets, from a group of 8 men and 6 women.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 181, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 101, 922, 136]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different ways the 10 people can be chosen if 6 of them are men and 4 of them are women.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 648, 477]]<|/det|>
The group of 8 men and 6 women contains a man and his wife.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 489, 181, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 488, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different ways the 10 people can be chosen if both the man and his wife are chosen or neither of them is chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Freddie has forgotten the 6-digit code that he uses to lock his briefcase. He knows that he did not repeat any digit and that he did not start his code with a zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 117, 180, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 722, 135]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different 6-digit numbers he could have chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 210, 638, 228]]<|/det|>
Freddie also remembers that his 6-digit code is divisible by 5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 241, 180, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 241, 722, 259]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different 6-digit numbers he could have chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 241, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 504, 920, 537]]<|/det|>
Freddie decides to choose a new 6-digit code for his briefcase once he has opened it. He plans to have the 6-digit number divisible by 2 and greater than 600 000, again with no repetitions of digits.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 551, 178, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 551, 665, 568]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different 6-digit numbers he can choose.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 551, 920, 568]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

Solve \(3\cos \mathrm{e}2x - 4\sin 2x = 0\) for \(0^{\circ}\leqslant x\leqslant 180^{\circ}.\)
